[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/British_Isles_Euler_diagram_15.svg/300px-
British_Isles_Euler_diagram_15.svg.png)](/wiki/File:British_Isles_Euler_diagram_15.svg)

[](/wiki/File:British_Isles_Euler_diagram_15.svg "Enlarge")

An [Euler diagram](/wiki/Euler_diagram "Euler diagram") with an overview of
the terminology  
 _Geographical feature_ Legal distinction

The **terminology of the British Isles** refers to the various words and
phrases that are used to describe the different (and sometimes overlapping)
geographical and political areas of the islands of [Great
Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland
"Ireland"), and the smaller islands which surround them. The terminology is
often a source of confusion, partly owing to the similarity between some of
the actual words used, but also because they are often used loosely. In
addition, many of the words carry both geographical and political connotations
which are affected by the history of the islands.

The purpose of this article is to explain the meanings of and relationships
among the terms in use; however many of these classifications are contentious
and are the subject of disagreement (See the [British Isles naming
dispute](/wiki/British_Isles_naming_dispute "British Isles naming dispute")).

##
Summary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Summary")]

The use of terminology depends on context; words and phrases can generally be
grouped into four main areas: geographical, political, linguistic and sporting
terms. In brief, the main terms and their simple explanations are as follows:

  * Geographical terms: 
    * The [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles") is a group of islands in the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") off the coast of [Continental Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe"). It includes [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), the [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"), [Shetland](/wiki/Shetland "Shetland"), [Orkney](/wiki/Orkney "Orkney"), and [thousands of smaller islands](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_British_Isles "List of islands of the British Isles"). Traditionally the [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") are included, though these specific islands are geographically closer to mainland continental Europe, being positioned off the French coast of [Normandy](/wiki/Normandy "Normandy"). This, in part, has resulted in the term being [disputed](/wiki/British_Isles_naming_dispute "British Isles naming dispute").[1][2]
      * **[Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain")** is the largest island of the [archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago").[3][4][5]
      * **[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland")** is the second largest island of the archipelago and lies directly to the west of Great Britain. The island of Ireland itself has its own **[list of Irish Isles](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Ireland "List of islands of Ireland")**.
      * The full **[list of islands of the British Isles](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_British_Isles "List of islands of the British Isles")** includes over 6,000 islands,[6] of which 51 have an area larger than 20 km2 (7.7 sq mi).
  * Political terms: 
    * The **[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")** is the [constitutional monarchy](/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") occupying the island of Great Britain, the small nearby islands (but not the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands), and the north-eastern part of the island of Ireland. Usually, it is shortened to _United Kingdom_ or _the UK_ , though _Britain_ is also an officially recognised short form. "Great Britain" is sometimes used as a short form, and is the name used by the UK in some international organisations.[7] The abbreviation _GB_ is frequently used for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in international agreements, e.g. [Universal Postal Union](/wiki/Universal_Postal_Union "Universal Postal Union") and [Road Traffic Convention](/wiki/Vienna_Convention_on_Road_Traffic "Vienna Convention on Road Traffic"), as well as in the [ISO 3166](/wiki/ISO_3166 "ISO 3166") country codes (GB and GBR). "England" was also formerly used [synecdochically](/wiki/Synecdoche "Synecdoche") to refer to the whole United Kingdom, but this usage became rare early in the 20th century.
    * **[Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland")** is the sovereign republic occupying the larger portion of the island of Ireland. However, to distinguish the state from the island, or to distinguish either of these from [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), it is also called "the Republic of Ireland" or simply "the Republic". Occasionally, its [Irish-language](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language") name, _[Éire](/wiki/%C3%89ire "Éire")_ (or _Eire_ without the diacritic), will be used in an English-language context to distinguish it from "Northern Ireland", even though the word _Éire_ directly translates as "Ireland".
    * [England](/wiki/England "England"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales") and [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") are the four [countries of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom "Countries of the United Kingdom"), though they are also referred to, especially in sporting contexts, as the [home nations](/wiki/Home_nations "Home nations") of the United Kingdom.
    * [England and Wales](/wiki/England_and_Wales "England and Wales"), Scotland, and Northern Ireland are legal jurisdictions within the United Kingdom.[8]
    * [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain#Political_definition "Great Britain") means the countries of England, Wales and Scotland considered as a unit.[9][10]
    * [British Islands](/wiki/British_Islands "British Islands") consists of the United Kingdom, the [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") and the [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"). These are the [polities](/wiki/Polity "Polity") within the British Isles that have the [British monarch](/wiki/British_monarch "British monarch") as head of state.
  * Linguistic terms: 
    * The two [sovereign states](/wiki/Sovereign_states "Sovereign states") in the region, the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and [Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"), are frequently referred to as _countries_. So too are [England](/wiki/England "England"), [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") and, to a lesser extent, [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") (as is the whole [island of Ireland](/wiki/Island_of_Ireland "Island of Ireland")).
    * British is an adjective pertaining to the United Kingdom; for example, a [citizen](/wiki/Citizen "Citizen") of the UK is called a [British citizen](/wiki/British_citizen "British citizen")—but for citizenship purposes "British" includes the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.
    * [Anglo-](/wiki/Anglo- "Anglo-") is often used as an adjectival prefix referring to the United Kingdom (notwithstanding that its original meaning is "English") particularly in the field of diplomatic relations. It can also refer to the English language, to anglophone peoples and can have a variety of other shades of meaning.
    * Wales is sometimes called the _[Principality of Wales](/wiki/Principality_of_Wales "Principality of Wales")_ , although this has no modern constitutional basis.
    * Northern Ireland is often referred to as a _province_ or called _Ulster_ , after the [traditional Irish province](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of Ireland") of [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") within which it is located.
  * Sport 
    * Forms of national representation vary from sport to sport. England, Scotland and Wales often compete separately as _nations_.[11] In some sports—such as [rugby](/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby football") and [cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket")—the island of Ireland competes as a nation; in others, most notably [association football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"), Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland field separate teams. In these contexts England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland/Northern Ireland are sometimes described as _the[home nations](/wiki/Home_nations "Home nations")_.
    * [Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") players from both Ireland and Great Britain play for [British and Irish Lions](/wiki/British_and_Irish_Lions "British and Irish Lions") representing the four "Home Unions" of [England](/wiki/Rugby_Football_Union "Rugby Football Union"), [Ireland](/wiki/Irish_Rugby_Football_Union "Irish Rugby Football Union"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scottish_Rugby_Union "Scottish Rugby Union") and [Wales](/wiki/Welsh_Rugby_Union "Welsh Rugby Union").
    * [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") is sometimes used to mean [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"). For example, at the [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"), the team called "Great Britain" represents Great Britain and Northern Ireland.[12][13] However, athletes from Northern Ireland have, by virtue of their entitlement to dual nationality, the choice of participating in either the Great Britain team or the Republic of Ireland team.[13]
    * In the majority of individual sports (e.g. [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") and [athletics](/wiki/Athletics_\(sport\) "Athletics \(sport\)")), at international level competitors are identified as GB if they are from Great Britain or Northern Ireland. A small number of sports (e.g. [golf](/wiki/Golf "Golf"), [darts](/wiki/Darts "Darts"), [snooker](/wiki/Snooker "Snooker")) identify participants as representing their constituent country. In the [Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games"), England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales each compete as separate nations, as do each of the three Crown Dependencies (Ireland is not part of the [Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") and is not eligible to participate).

## Terminology in
detail[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Terminology in detail")]

  * **[Britain](/wiki/Britain_\(name\) "Britain \(name\)")** is a political and geographic term which can refer to the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland"),[14] or the island of [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain").
  * **[Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain")** is the [largest island](/wiki/List_of_islands_by_area "List of islands by area") in Europe and the [political union](/wiki/Political_union "Political union") of three nations, these being:

    

    

  * **[England and Wales](/wiki/England_and_Wales "England and Wales")** is a political and administrative term referring to the two [home countries](/wiki/Home_countries "Home countries") of England and Wales, which share the same legal system. Between [1746](/wiki/Wales_and_Berwick_Act_1746 "Wales and Berwick Act 1746") and [1967](/wiki/Welsh_Language_Act_1967 "Welsh Language Act 1967") the term "England" did legally include Wales.

    

  * **[England](/wiki/England "England")** (see also the historical [Kingdom of England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England")).
  * **[Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales")** (see also the historical [Principality of Wales](/wiki/Principality_of_Wales "Principality of Wales")).

  * **[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland")** (see also the historical [Kingdom of Scotland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland "Kingdom of Scotland"))

    

  * The historical **[Kingdom of Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain")** is Britain for the period 1707–1801.
  * **Britannia** is the [Roman province of Britain](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain"), or a poetic reference to later Britain, or a [personification of Britain](/wiki/Britannia "Britannia").

  * The **[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland")** , usually shortened to the **United Kingdom** (abbreviation **UK**), is the [sovereign state](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") comprising [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain#Political_definition "Great Britain") plus **Northern Ireland** since 1927. (The Partition of Ireland took place in 1922, but the consequent change in the official title of the UK was only made by Act of Parliament five years later.) The [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland") is often shortened to **Britain** , even on official websites.[15][16] A proposal to rename the political entity as the "[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ulster](/wiki/Alternative_names_for_Northern_Ireland "Alternative names for Northern Ireland")" was formally recommended by civil servants to the Cabinet in 1949 but ultimately rejected.[17]

    

  * The historical **[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland")** was [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain#Political_definition "Great Britain") plus [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), for the period 1801 to 1922, although the name change after the secession of the Irish Free State only took place in 1927.

    N.B.: While "United Kingdom" is normally abbreviated **UK** , the official [ISO 3166](/wiki/ISO_3166 "ISO 3166") two-letter country code is **GB** and the three letter code is **GBR** ([Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine") has the two letter code UA and the three letter code UKR). Due to a pre-existing convention originating in the UK's [JANET](/wiki/JANET "JANET") academic computer network,[18] the UK's [Internet top-level domain](/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain "Country code top-level domain") is **[.uk](/wiki/.uk ".uk")** , a break from the [TCP/IP](/wiki/TCP/IP "TCP/IP") practice of following ISO 3166 (a **[.gb](/wiki/.gb ".gb")** domain has also been used to a limited extent in the past but is now defunct). **GB** is also used on car number plates to indicate the United Kingdom.

  * **[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland")** (in [Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"), _**Éire**_) refers, geographically, to the island of Ireland, or to any of the following:

    _Historically:_

  * The **[Kingdom of Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland")** was Ireland for the period 1541–1801. (The [King of Ireland](/wiki/King_of_Ireland "King of Ireland") remained Head of State in the Irish Free State and Ireland/Éire until the [Republic of Ireland Act 1948](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_Act_1948 "Republic of Ireland Act 1948") abolished that status).
  * The **[Irish Republic](/wiki/Irish_Republic "Irish Republic")** , established by the [Irish Declaration of Independence](/wiki/Irish_Declaration_of_Independence "Irish Declaration of Independence"), was a 32-county republic encompassing the entire island, during the period 1919–22—though its _de facto_ rule did not encompass all of the island. During this period, according to British law, Ireland remained part of the UK though its independence was recognised by [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia").
  * **[Southern Ireland](/wiki/Southern_Ireland_\(1921%E2%80%9322\) "Southern Ireland \(1921–22\)")** was a proposed [Home Rule](/wiki/Home_Rule "Home Rule") 26-county state under the [Government of Ireland Act 1920](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1920 "Government of Ireland Act 1920"). It never came into practical existence, being superseded by:
  * The **[Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State")** is Ireland excepting Northern Ireland during the period 1922–37.

    _Present_ : 

  * **Ireland** (in [Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"), _[Éire](/wiki/%C3%89ire "Éire")_) is the political entity consisting of the island of Ireland excepting Northern Ireland, 1937–present. This is the name of the state according to the [Irish Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Ireland "Constitution of Ireland") and the United Nations.
  * The **[Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland")** is a commonly used description of Ireland excepting Northern Ireland, 1949–present. It is also the name used by the international [Association Football](/wiki/Association_Football "Association Football") team.

    The terms _Irish Republic_ , _Southern Ireland_ , the _Irish Free State_ , the _Free State_ , the _26 Counties_ and _Éire_ (in English-language texts) have been used synonymously with the _Republic of Ireland_. Of these, _Southern Ireland_ and _Irish Free State_ , in particular, are seen as outdated. "Eire" (spelt without the Irish _[fada](/wiki/Acute_accent "Acute accent")_) was the British legal spelling from the [Eire (Confirmation of Agreements) Act 1938](/wiki/Eire_\(Confirmation_of_Agreements\)_Act_1938 "Eire \(Confirmation of Agreements\) Act 1938") until the [Ireland Act 1949](/wiki/Ireland_Act_1949 "Ireland Act 1949"), and informally for some years after.

  * **[Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland")** 1922–present. That part of the island of Ireland northeast of the line of partition of 1922, and which is still part of the United Kingdom. [Various alternative names](/wiki/Alternative_names_for_Northern_Ireland "Alternative names for Northern Ireland") have been used or proposed for Northern Ireland. It is sometimes referred to as "the North of Ireland", "the Six Counties" or (in extremist usage) the "occupied six counties", especially by [Irish Nationalists](/wiki/Irish_Nationalism "Irish Nationalism").
  * **[Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster")**. The name of one of Ireland's four traditional [provinces](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of Ireland"). The area contains nine northern counties, six of which make up [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), and three of which are part of the [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"). It is also often used by [Unionists](/wiki/Unionism_in_Ireland "Unionism in Ireland") to refer to the smaller [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"). Though [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") has not been a political entity since the ancient Gaelic provincial kingdoms, it remains associated with a geographical area and is used in sporting and cultural contexts. See [Ulster (disambiguation)](/wiki/Ulster_\(disambiguation\) "Ulster \(disambiguation\)").

    _In sport_

  * In [Gaelic games](/wiki/Gaelic_games "Gaelic games"), no distinction is recognised between the [GAA counties](/wiki/GAA_county "GAA county") of the Republic and those of Northern Ireland. County teams play in their provincial championships (where the six counties of Ulster within Northern Ireland and three within the Republic all play in the Ulster championship) and the winners of these play in the All-Ireland championship. Even within Northern Ireland, a tricolour, the [flag of the Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Flag_of_Ireland "Flag of Ireland"), is flown at all games. At bigger games, where an anthem is played, it is always [the national anthem of the Republic](/wiki/Amhr%C3%A1n_na_bhFiann "Amhrán na bhFiann"). In the case of the [International Rules](/wiki/International_rules_football "International rules football") series against [Australia](/wiki/Australia_international_rules_football_team "Australia international rules football team"), an Irish national team is chosen from all 32 counties.
  * In Association Football, the teams correspond to political entities: Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. In accordance with [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") and [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA")'s rules, each of these countries has its own football league: the [Irish League](/wiki/Irish_Football_League "Irish Football League") and the [League of Ireland](/wiki/League_of_Ireland "League of Ireland") respectively.
  * In [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union"), [rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league"), [field hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey"), [cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket"), [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"), [golf](/wiki/Golf "Golf"), [athletics](/wiki/Athletics_\(sport\) "Athletics \(sport\)") and others the _Ireland_ team is drawn from the whole island (i.e. both the Republic and Northern Ireland). Many sports organisations are subdivided along provincial lines e.g. [Gaelic Athletic Association](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic Association"), [golf](/wiki/Golf "Golf").

  * The **[British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles")** is a term used to mean the island of Great Britain plus the island of Ireland and many smaller surrounding islands, including the [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man") and, in some contexts, the [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") ([Guernsey](/wiki/Guernsey "Guernsey") and [Jersey](/wiki/Jersey "Jersey")). See [British Isles naming dispute](/wiki/British_Isles_naming_dispute "British Isles naming dispute") for details of the conflict over use of this term.
  * _Great Britain and Ireland_ , or variants like "Britain and Ireland" or "The UK and Ireland" are sometimes used as alternatives to the term [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles").
  * **Anglo-Celtic Isles** is an alternative term (in limited use) for the geographic region comprising Britain & Ireland, more commonly referred to as the 'British Isles'. 'Anglo-Celtic Islands' is a derivative of this. It is intended as a geographic term free of any political implication and uses the macro-cultural grouping term [Anglo-Celtic](/wiki/Anglo-Celtic "Anglo-Celtic"), referring to the peoples from which the majority of the island group's population are descended—the [Anglo-Saxons](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons") and the [Celts](/wiki/Celt "Celt") (it can also be inclusive of the [Anglo-Normans](/wiki/Anglo-Normans "Anglo-Normans")).
  * **[Islands of the North Atlantic](/wiki/Islands_of_the_North_Atlantic "Islands of the North Atlantic")** is another suggested replacement term for 'British Isles', without the same political connotations. However, its convolution and impracticality due to implying inclusion of fellow North Atlantic islands such as Iceland have made it unworkable and it has not come into common use. The term was used as part of the Strand 3 level of negotiations for the Belfast agreement. (Its acronym, IONA, is also the name of the small but historically important island of [Iona](/wiki/Iona "Iona") off the coast of Scotland.)
  * **[British Islands](/wiki/British_Islands "British Islands")** (a legal term not in common usage) is the UK, the Isle of Man, and the Channel Islands.
  * **[Brittany](/wiki/Brittany "Brittany")** , itself a corruption of 'Britain', and sometimes formerly known as 'Little Britain' is a historical [Duchy](/wiki/Duchy "Duchy") in the West of [France](/wiki/France "France"), now a French region; for this modern administrative sense, see [Brittany (administrative region)](/wiki/Brittany_\(administrative_region\) "Brittany \(administrative region\)").

## Geographical
distinctions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Geographical distinctions")]

### The British
Isles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: The British Isles")]

[![British Isles all.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/British_Isles_all.svg/50px-British_Isles_all.svg.png)](/wiki/File:British_Isles_all.svg) |  The [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles") is a group of islands in the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") off the coast of [Continental Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe"). It includes [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), the [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man"), [Shetland](/wiki/Shetland "Shetland"), [Orkney](/wiki/Orkney "Orkney"), and [thousands of smaller islands](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_British_Isles "List of islands of the British Isles"). Traditionally the [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands"), are included, however these specific islands are geographically part of mainland continental Europe, as they are positioned off the French coast of Normandy. The term is disputed (see [British Isles naming dispute](/wiki/British_Isles_naming_dispute "British Isles naming dispute")).  
---|---  
  
#### Great
Britain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Great Britain")]

[![Great Britain.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Great_Britain.svg/50px-Great_Britain.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Great_Britain.svg) | [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") is the largest of the British Isles. On Great Britain are located three constituent countries of the United Kingdom: [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") in the north, [England](/wiki/England "England") in the south and east and [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales") in the west. There are also [numerous smaller islands](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_the_British_Isles "List of islands of the British Isles") off its coast (_not_ coloured red on the attached map) that are administered as part of England, Scotland and Wales. The inclusion of these smaller islands means political 'Great Britain' covers a slightly larger area than the island of Great Britain.  
---|---

Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=7

[![Island of Ireland.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Island_of_Ireland.svg/50px-Island_of_Ireland.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Island_of_Ireland.svg) | The second largest island in the group is [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"). Most of the island is in the [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"). The north east of the island ([Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland")) is part of the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"). There are also [numerous smaller islands](/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Ireland "List of islands of Ireland") off the coast of Ireland.
