## Political terms in more
detail[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Political terms in more detail")]

### The United
Kingdom[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: The United Kingdom")]

[![British Isles United
Kingdom.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/British_Isles_United_Kingdom.svg/80px-
British_Isles_United_Kingdom.svg.png)](/wiki/File:British_Isles_United_Kingdom.svg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/British_passport_2002.jpg/130px-
British_passport_2002.jpg)](/wiki/File:British_passport_2002.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:British_passport_2002.jpg "Enlarge")

A UK passport

_The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland_ is the official
full title of the state. This name appears on official documentation such as
[British passports](/wiki/British_passport "British passport"). For
convenience, the name is usually shortened to _United Kingdom_ , _UK_ or
_Britain_.[9]

The **United Kingdom** is a [sovereign state](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign
state"). Its four [constituent
countries](/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom "Countries of the United
Kingdom") are sometimes considered to be of different status. This view may be
supported by the existence of [devolved](/wiki/Devolution "Devolution")
governments with different levels of power in Scotland, Northern Ireland and
Wales (see [Asymmetrical federalism](/wiki/Asymmetrical_federalism
"Asymmetrical federalism")).

Wales is also often erroneously[19] described as a
[principality](/wiki/Principality "Principality") of the United Kingdom. The
title of [Prince of Wales](/wiki/Prince_of_Wales "Prince of Wales") is usually
given to the [heir apparent](/wiki/Heir_apparent "Heir apparent") to the
[British throne](/wiki/British_throne "British throne") but it has no
political or other role in respect of Wales. The [International Organization
for Standardisation](/wiki/International_Organization_for_Standardisation
"International Organization for Standardisation") (ISO) has defined Wales as a
"country" rather than a "principality" since 2011, following a recommendation
by the [British Standards Institute](/wiki/British_Standards_Institute
"British Standards Institute") and the [Welsh
Government](/wiki/Welsh_Government "Welsh Government").[20]

[Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") is sometimes
described by [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") citizens
as a [province](/wiki/Province "Province") of the United Kingdom, which
derives from the Irish [province](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of
Ireland") of [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"), of which [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") is a part. Northern
Ireland also had, until 1972, a far greater degree of [self-
government](/wiki/Self-government "Self-government") than the other
constituent parts of the UK.

_Great Britain_ is both a geographical and a political entity. Geographically,
it is one island, but [as a political
entity](/wiki/Great_Britain#Political_definition "Great Britain") it also
includes the smaller offshore islands that are administered as part of its
constituent nations – England, Wales and Scotland – such as England's [Isle of
Wight](/wiki/Isle_of_Wight "Isle of Wight"), Wales' [Anglesey](/wiki/Anglesey
"Anglesey") and Scotland's [Inner Hebrides](/wiki/Inner_Hebrides "Inner
Hebrides"), [Outer Hebrides](/wiki/Outer_Hebrides "Outer Hebrides"), [Orkney
Islands](/wiki/Orkney_Islands "Orkney Islands") and [Shetland
Islands](/wiki/Shetland_Islands "Shetland Islands").

The abbreviation _GB_ is sometimes officially used for the United Kingdom, for
example in the [Olympics](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"), or as the
[vehicle registration
plate](/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plate#International_codes "Vehicle
registration plate") [country identification
code](/wiki/List_of_international_license_plate_codes "List of international
license plate codes") for UK-registered cars _(see also[British car number
plates](/wiki/British_car_number_plates "British car number plates"))_. _SCO_
in Scotland, _CYM_ for Wales (Cymru), _NI_ for Northern Ireland, or _ENG_ for
England can also be used.[21]

The [internet code](/wiki/Internet_code "Internet code") _[.gb](/wiki/.gb
".gb"),_ although allocated to the UK, is virtually unused and UK web domains
use _[.uk](/wiki/.uk ".uk")_.

The four constituent parts of the UK are also known, particularly in sporting
contexts, as _[Home Nations](/wiki/Home_Nations "Home Nations")_ or the "Four
Nations". The BBC refers to its UK-wide broadcasting operation as _Nations and
Regions_ [22] ("regions" referring to geographic regions of England. Thus the
UK naming conventions tend towards describing distinct _regions_ or _nations_
which exist within a single sovereign _state_.

In sport, the UK Nations mostly have their own separate national teams –
England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, for example in
[football](/wiki/Football_\(soccer\) "Football \(soccer\)"). Sporting contests
between the Four Nations are known as "Home internationals" (an example is the
[British Home Championship](/wiki/British_Home_Championship "British Home
Championship") in football).

The governing body for football in Northern Ireland is called the [Irish
Football Association](/wiki/Irish_Football_Association "Irish Football
Association") (the IFA), having been in existence since some forty years
before [Partition](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland "Partition of Ireland"). Its
counterpart in the Republic (plus [Derry City FC](/wiki/Derry_City_FC "Derry
City FC")) is the [Football Association of
Ireland](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Ireland "Football Association of
Ireland") (the FAI). The [Northern Ireland national
team](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland national
football team") retained the name "Ireland" for some fifty years after
partition. Since around 1970 the two teams have been consistently referred to
as "Northern Ireland" and "[Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of Ireland
national football team")" respectively. The UK competes as Great Britain at
the Olympic Games. According to the Olympic Charter the Olympic Council of
Ireland represents the entire island of Ireland.[23] Olympic athletes from
Northern Ireland may choose whether to represent the UK or the [Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland").

Since the [Good Friday Agreement](/wiki/Good_Friday_Agreement "Good Friday
Agreement") and the subsequent implementation legislation, sporting
organisation (and several other organisations, e.g.
[tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Ireland "Tourism in Ireland"), [Irish
Gaelic](/wiki/Irish_Gaelic "Irish Gaelic") and [Ulster
Scots](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects "Ulster Scots dialects") language boards)
on the island of Ireland has increasingly been cross-border.

Citizens of the UK are called _British_ , _Brits_ , _Britons_ or _Britisher_
(archaic). The term _Unionists_ may also be used, sometimes
[pejoratively](/wiki/Pejoratively "Pejoratively"), for example by supporters
of [Scottish independence](/wiki/Scottish_independence "Scottish
independence") when referring to supporters of the
[Union](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707 "Acts of Union 1707"). Some older slang names
for Britons are _Tommy_ (for British soldiers) and _Anglo_.
[Anglo](/wiki/Anglo "Anglo") properly refers only to England, but it is
sometimes used as a broader reference as an element in compound adjectives:
for example, "Anglo-French relations" may be used in newspaper articles when
referring to relations between the political entities [France](/wiki/France
"France") and the United Kingdom. _Anglo-Saxon_ may be used (particularly in
Continental European languages) when referring to the whole [English-speaking
world](/wiki/English-speaking_world "English-speaking world").

###
Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Ireland")]

Main article: [Names of the Irish state](/wiki/Names_of_the_Irish_state "Names
of the Irish state")

[![Republic of
Ireland.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Republic_of_Ireland.svg/80px-
Republic_of_Ireland.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Republic_of_Ireland.svg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/130px-
Eirepas.JPG)](/wiki/File:Eirepas.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Eirepas.JPG "Enlarge")

An Irish passport

Since the adoption of the [Constitution of
Ireland](/wiki/Constitution_of_Ireland "Constitution of Ireland") in 1937,
**[Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland")** has been the
[English](/wiki/English_\(language\) "English \(language\)") name of the state
which covers approximately five-sixths of the island of
[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"). The name **[Éire](/wiki/%C3%89ire
"Éire")** is used when writing in [Irish](/wiki/Irish_\(language\) "Irish
\(language\)").

Since the [Republic of Ireland Act 1948](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_Act_1948
"Republic of Ireland Act 1948"), the term "Republic of Ireland" is the term
used as the additional _description_ of the state. This term is useful in
avoiding ambiguity between the name of the island and the name of the state.
However, the term "Ireland" is always used in formal diplomatic contexts such
as the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") or the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"). The passport of the Republic
of Ireland bears the name _Éire – Ireland_.

Before the introduction of the 1937 constitution and the new name, the [Irish
Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") occupied the same
territory as the modern state of Ireland. The Irish Free State became an
autonomous [dominion](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion") of the [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") in 1922 when it seceded from
the United Kingdom through the [Anglo-Irish Treaty](/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty
"Anglo-Irish Treaty"). The King ceased to be its Head of State [in
1936](/wiki/Executive_Authority_\(External_Relations\)_Act_1936 "Executive
Authority \(External Relations\) Act 1936") and the state ceased to be a
Dominion and left the Commonwealth [in
1948](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_Act_1948 "Republic of Ireland Act 1948").

Traditionally, the island of Ireland is divided into four
[provinces](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of Ireland") –
[Leinster](/wiki/Leinster "Leinster"), [Connacht](/wiki/Connacht "Connacht"),
[Munster](/wiki/Munster "Munster") and [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"), with
each of the provinces further divided into counties. The Republic of Ireland
takes up 83% of the island, twenty-six of the thirty-two traditional counties
of Ireland. Northern Ireland takes up the remaining area, six of the
traditional nine counties of Ulster.

On the island of Ireland the naming of places often raises political issues.
The usage of "Ireland" as the [official name](/wiki/Constitution_of_Ireland
"Constitution of Ireland") of the state causes offence to some
[Unionists](/wiki/Unionists_\(Ireland\) "Unionists \(Ireland\)") in [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), who believe it implies
that the state
[still](/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_of_the_Constitution_of_Ireland "Nineteenth
Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland") has a territorial claim to the
whole island – the terminology of "Republic of Ireland" or
"[Éire](/wiki/%C3%89ire "Éire")" is much preferred by Northern Irish unionists
when referring to that political state. Similarly, some
[Nationalists](/wiki/Nationalists_\(Ireland\) "Nationalists \(Ireland\)") in
Northern Ireland also prefer to reserve the usage of "Ireland" to refer to the
whole island.

In Northern Ireland, Irishness is a highly contested identity, with
fundamentally different perceptions of national identity between unionists
(who generally perceive themselves as being British) and nationalists (who
generally consider both communities to be part of the Irish nation).[24]

The Republic of Ireland is often referred to by the
[Nationalist](/wiki/Irish_nationalists "Irish nationalists") and
[Republican](/wiki/Irish_Republicans "Irish Republicans") communities by the
term "the Twenty-six Counties", with the connotation that the state
constituted as such forms only a portion of the ideal political unit of the
[Irish Republic](/wiki/Irish_Republic "Irish Republic"), which would consist
of all of the [thirty-two counties](/wiki/Counties_of_Ireland "Counties of
Ireland") into which the island is divided. The term "the Six Counties" (of
Northern Ireland) is also used. Other Nationalist terms in use include "the
North of Ireland" and "the North". These latter are terms also used by the
Irish national broadcaster [RTÉ](/wiki/Raidi%C3%B3_Teilif%C3%ADs_%C3%89ireann
"Raidió Teilifís Éireann").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] More extreme terms for Northern Ireland include
"the occupied six counties" or "occupied Ireland", which are often used by
people who reject the idea of Northern Ireland as a separate entity from the
Republic of Ireland.

The [Irish passport](/wiki/Irish_passport "Irish passport") is available to
Irish citizens and can also be applied for abroad through Irish Consular
services and the local Irish Embassy. As per the [Irish nationality
law](/wiki/Irish_nationality_law "Irish nationality law"), any person born on
the island of Ireland before 2005, or otherwise a first generation descendant
of such a person, is allowed to apply for an Irish passport. As such, people
born in Northern Ireland and their children may be Irish citizens and hold an
Irish passport if they choose.

### British
Islands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: British Islands")]

[![British
Islands.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/British_Islands.svg/80px-
British_Islands.svg.png)](/wiki/File:British_Islands.svg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Jersey_passport_new.jpg/130px-
Jersey_passport_new.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jersey_passport_new.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jersey_passport_new.jpg "Enlarge")

A Jersey passport

Under the Interpretation Act 1978 of the United Kingdom, the legal term
_**British Islands**_ (as opposed to the geographical term _British Isles_)
refers to the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United
Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland"), together with the [Crown
dependencies](/wiki/Crown_dependencies "Crown dependencies"): the
[Bailiwicks](/wiki/Bailiwick "Bailiwick") of [Jersey](/wiki/Jersey "Jersey")
and of [Guernsey](/wiki/Guernsey "Guernsey") (which in turn includes the
smaller islands of [Alderney](/wiki/Alderney "Alderney"), [Herm](/wiki/Herm
"Herm") and [Sark](/wiki/Sark "Sark")) in the [Channel
Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands"); and the [Isle of
Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man").

Special British passports are issued to citizens of the Crown dependencies. On
the front of passports issued to residents of the Crown dependencies, the
words _" United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland"_ are replaced
with _" British Islands"_ followed by the name of the issuing state or island.
This design applies to [Jersey passport](/wiki/Jersey_passport "Jersey
passport"), [Guernsey passport](/wiki/Guernsey_passport "Guernsey passport")
and [Isle of Man passport](/wiki/Isle_of_Man_passport "Isle of Man passport").
Like UK passports, Crown dependency also bear the title _" European Union"_
for customs purposes. However, Crown dependency citizens who have no family
ties to the United Kingdom are granted a special limited "Islander Status"
under EU law (article 6 of Protocol 3 in the [Treaty of Accession of the UK to
the European Community](/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_1972 "Treaty of Accession
1972")).[25][26]

## Historical
aspects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Historical aspects")]

Further information: [Britain (name)](/wiki/Britain_\(name\) "Britain
\(name\)")

Some suggest an early known for the term might be from [ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") writings. Though some of the
original texts have been lost, excerpts were quoted or paraphrased by later
authors. Parts of the [Massaliote Periplus](/wiki/Massaliote_Periplus
"Massaliote Periplus"), a merchants' handbook describing searoutes of the
sixth century BC, were used in translation in the writings of
[Avienus](/wiki/Avienus "Avienus") around AD 400. Ireland was referred to as
_Ierne_ (_Insula sacra_ , the _sacred island_ , as the Greeks interpreted it)
"inhabited by the race of _Hiberni_ " (_gens hiernorum_), and Britain as
_insula Albionum_ , "island of the [Albions](/wiki/Albion "Albion")".[27]
Several sources from around 150 BC to AD 70 include fragments of the travel
writings of the ancient Greek [Pytheas](/wiki/Pytheas "Pytheas") around 320
BC, use the terms _Albion_ and _Ierne_[28][29] and have been described as
referring to the British Isles, including Ireland, as the _Prettanic_ or
_Brettanic Islands_ (Βρεττανικαὶ νῆσοι) or as αἱ Βρεττανιαι, literally "the
Britains".[27][29][30] Greek writers called the peoples of these islands the
Πρεττανοί, later Bρεττανοί (alternative spellings of this and of all relative
words have a single [tau](/wiki/Tau "Tau") or a double
[nu](/wiki/Nu_\(letter\) "Nu \(letter\)")), a name that possibly corresponds
to the _[Priteni](/wiki/Priteni "Priteni")_.[27] These names may have derived
from a "[Celtic language](/wiki/Celtic_languages "Celtic languages")" term
which may have reached Pytheas from the [Gauls](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul")[30] who may
have used it as their term for the inhabitants of the islands.

The Romans called the inhabitants of Gaul (modern [France](/wiki/France
"France")) _Galli_ or _Celtae_ , the latter term deriving from the Greek name
Κελτοί for a central European people. Antiquarians of the seventeenth century
who found language connections developed the idea of a race of
[Celts](/wiki/Celt "Celt") inhabiting the islands, but this term was not used
by the Greeks or Romans for the inhabitants of Britain or Ireland,[31] nor is
there any record of the inhabitants of the British Isles referring to
themselves as such. Nevertheless, Roman administration later incorporated the
province of Britannia into the [praetorian prefecture of
Gaul](/wiki/Praetorian_prefecture_of_Gaul "Praetorian prefecture of Gaul"), in
common with Hispania, which had Celtiberians. [Armorica](/wiki/Armorica
"Armorica"), where the Bretons would
settle[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_], was part of _Gallia Celtica_
, so there were tertiary relations between the Britons and Gallic Celts at
least. In addition, the [Parisii](/wiki/Parisii_\(Gaul\) "Parisii \(Gaul\)")
of Gallia Celtica are thought to have founded Aldborough in Britain.
[Belgae](/wiki/Belgae "Belgae") and [Silures](/wiki/Silures "Silures") also
came from Gallic areas, although not strictly "Celtic", but from _Gallia
Belgica_ and _Aquitainia_.

_Priteni_ is the source of the [Welsh language](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh
language") term [Prydain](/wiki/Prydain "Prydain"), _Britain_ ,[30] and has
the same source as the [Goidelic](/wiki/Goidelic_languages "Goidelic
languages") term [Cruithne](/wiki/Cruithne_\(people\) "Cruithne \(people\)").
The latter referred to the early [Brythonic](/wiki/Brythonic_languages
"Brythonic languages") speaking inhabitants of the [Scottish
highlands](/wiki/Scottish_highlands "Scottish highlands") and the north of
Scotland,[30] who are known as the Cruithne in [Scottish
Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic "Scottish Gaelic"), and who the
[Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") called [Picts](/wiki/Picts
"Picts") or [Caledonians](/wiki/Caledonians "Caledonians").

###
Romans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Romans")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Roman_britain_400.jpg/220px-
Roman_britain_400.jpg)](/wiki/File:Roman_britain_400.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Roman_britain_400.jpg "Enlarge")

Roman Britain in 410

[Caesar's invasions of Britain](/wiki/Caesar%27s_invasions_of_Britain
"Caesar's invasions of Britain") brought descriptions of the peoples of what
he called _Britannia pars interior_ , "inland Britain", in 55 BC. Throughout
Book 4 of his _Geography_ , [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") is consistent in
spelling the island Britain (transliterated) as _Prettanikē_ ; he uses the
terms _Prettans_ or _Brettans_ loosely to refer to the islands as a group – a
common generalisation used by classical geographers. For example, in Geography
2.1.18, _…οι νοτιώτατοι των Βρεττανών βορειότεροι τούτων εισίν_ ("…the most
southern of the Brettans are further north than this").[32] He was writing
around AD 10, although the earliest surviving copy of his work dates from the
6th century. [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder")
writing around AD 70 uses a Latin version of the same terminology in section
4.102 of his _[Naturalis Historia](/wiki/Pliny%27s_Natural_History "Pliny's
Natural History")_. He writes of Great Britain: _Albion ipsi nomen fuit, cum
Britanniae vocarentur omnes de quibus mox paulo dicemus._ ("Albion was its own
name, when all [the islands] were called the Britannias; I will speak of them
in a moment"). In the following section, 4.103, Pliny enumerates the islands
he considers to make up the Britannias, listing Great Britain, Ireland, and
many smaller islands. In his _Geography_ written in the mid 2nd century and
probably describing the position around AD 100,[30] [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy
"Ptolemy") includes both Great Britain (Albion) and Ireland
([Iwernia](/wiki/Hibernia "Hibernia")) in the so called _Bretanic_ island
group. He entitles Book II, Chapter 1 of as _[Iwernia](/wiki/Hibernia
"Hibernia"), Bretanic Island_, and Chapter 2 as _Alwion [sic], Bretanic
Island_.[33]

The name _Albion_ for [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain")
fell from favour, and the island was described in Greek as Πρεττανία or
Βρεττανία, in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") _Britannia_ , an inhabitant as
Βρεττανός, _Britannus_ , with the adjective Βρεττανικός, _Britannicus_ ,
equating to "British".[27] With the [Roman conquest of
Britain](/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Britain "Roman conquest of Britain") the name
[Britannia](/wiki/Britannia "Britannia") was used for the province of [Roman
Britain](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain"). The Emperor
[Claudius](/wiki/Claudius "Claudius") was honoured with the
[agnomen](/wiki/Roman_naming_convention "Roman naming convention")
_Britannicus_ as if he were the conqueror, and coins were struck from AD 46
inscribed DE BRITAN, DE BRITANN, DE BRITANNI, or DE BRITANNIS. With the visit
of [Hadrian](/wiki/Hadrian "Hadrian") in AD 121 coins introduced a female
figure with the label BRITANNIA as a personification or goddess of the place.
These and later Roman coins introduced the seated figure of Britannia which
would be reintroduced in the 17th century.[34]

In the later years of Roman rule Britons who left Latin inscriptions, both at
home and elsewhere in the Empire, often described themselves as _Brittanus_ or
_Britto_ , and where describing their citizenship gave it as _cives_ of a
British tribe or of a _patria_ (homeland) of _Britannia_ , not _Roma_.[27]
From the 4th century, many Britons migrated from Roman Britain across the
[English Channel](/wiki/English_Channel "English Channel") and founded
[Brittany](/wiki/Brittany "Brittany").

### Mediaeval
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Mediaeval period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Britain_802.jpg/220px-
Britain_802.jpg)](/wiki/File:Britain_802.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Britain_802.jpg "Enlarge")

Map of Britain with part of Ireland in 802

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Hereford_Mappa_Mundi_1300.jpg/220px-
Hereford_Mappa_Mundi_1300.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hereford_Mappa_Mundi_1300.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hereford_Mappa_Mundi_1300.jpg "Enlarge")

Hereford Mappa Mundi with the isles in the lower left hand corner.

While Latin remained the language of learning, from the early
[mediaeval](/wiki/Mediaeval "Mediaeval") period records begin to appear in
native languages. The earliest [indigenous](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples
"Indigenous peoples") source to use a collective term for the archipelago is
the _[Life of Saint
Columba](/w/index.php?title=Life_of_Saint_Columba&action=edit&redlink=1 "Life
of Saint Columba \(page does not exist\)")_ , a
[hagiography](/wiki/Hagiography "Hagiography") recording the missionary
activities of the sixth century Irish monk [Saint Columba](/wiki/Saint_Columba
"Saint Columba") among the peoples of what is now Scotland. It was written in
the late seventh century by [Adomnán](/wiki/Adomn%C3%A1n_of_Iona "Adomnán of
Iona") of [Iona](/wiki/Iona "Iona"), an Irish monk living on the [Inner
Hebridean](/wiki/Inner_Hebridean "Inner Hebridean") island. The collective
term for the archipelago used within this work is **Oceani Insulae** meaning
"Islands of the Ocean" (Book 2, 46 in the Sharpe edition = Book 2, 47 in
Reeves edition), it is used sparingly and no _Priteni_ -derived collective
reference is made.

Another early native source to use a collective term is the _[Historia
ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum](/wiki/Historia_ecclesiastica_gentis_Anglorum
"Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum")_ of [Bede](/wiki/Bede "Bede")
written in the early eighth century. The collective term for the archipelago
used within this work is _insularum_ meaning "islands" (Book 1, 8) and it too
is used sparingly. He stated that Britain "studies and confesses one and the
same knowledge of the highest truth in the tongues of five nations, namely the
Angles, the Britons, the Scots, the Picts, and the Latins", distinguishing
between the [Brythonic languages](/wiki/Brythonic_languages "Brythonic
languages") of the "ancient Britons" or [Old Welsh](/wiki/Old_Welsh "Old
Welsh") speakers and other language groups.[35]

[Brythonic](/wiki/Britons_\(Celtic_people\) "Britons \(Celtic people\)"),
[Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons") and [Viking](/wiki/Viking "Viking")
kingdoms such as [Strathclyde](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Strathclyde "Kingdom of
Strathclyde"), [Wessex](/wiki/Wessex "Wessex"), and
[Jórvík](/wiki/Scandinavian_York "Scandinavian York") amalgamated, leading to
the formation of [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), and
[England](/wiki/England "England"). [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales") was sometimes
united under princes or kings such as [Gruffydd ap
Llywelyn](/wiki/Gruffydd_ap_Llywelyn "Gruffydd ap Llywelyn"). Between 854 and
1171, a kingship of Ireland was established by kings of the regional kingdoms
such as [Máel Sechnaill mac Máele
Ruanaid](/wiki/M%C3%A1el_Sechnaill_mac_M%C3%A1ele_Ruanaid "Máel Sechnaill mac
Máele Ruanaid"), [Toirdelbach Ua Briain](/wiki/Toirdelbach_Ua_Briain
"Toirdelbach Ua Briain"), [Muirchertach Mac
Lochlainn](/wiki/Muirchertach_Mac_Lochlainn "Muirchertach Mac Lochlainn"), and
[Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair](/wiki/Ruaidr%C3%AD_Ua_Conchobair "Ruaidrí Ua
Conchobair"), something not achieved in Britain until 1707. In subsequent
[Norman Ireland](/wiki/Norman_Ireland "Norman Ireland"), local lords gained
considerable autonomy from the [Lordship of Ireland](/wiki/Lordship_of_Ireland
"Lordship of Ireland") until it became the [Kingdom of
Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland") under direct English
rule.

### Renaissance
mapmakers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Renaissance mapmakers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Blaeu_-
_Atlas_of_Scotland_1654_-_INSULAE_ALBION_ET_HIBERNIA_-
_Old_Great_Britain.jpg/220px-Blaeu_-
_Atlas_of_Scotland_1654_-_INSULAE_ALBION_ET_HIBERNIA_-
_Old_Great_Britain.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blaeu_-
_Atlas_of_Scotland_1654_-_INSULAE_ALBION_ET_HIBERNIA_-_Old_Great_Britain.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Blaeu_-_Atlas_of_Scotland_1654_-_INSULAE_ALBION_ET_HIBERNIA_-
_Old_Great_Britain.jpg "Enlarge")

The 1654 Blaeu Atlas of Scotland, _Insulae Albion Et Hibernia_

[Abraham Ortelius](/wiki/Abraham_Ortelius "Abraham Ortelius") makes clear his
understanding that England, Scotland and Ireland were politically separate in
1570 by the full title of his map: _Angliae, Scotiae et Hiberniae, sive
Britannicar. insularum descriptio_ ('A representation of England, Scotland and
Ireland, or the Britannic islands'). [George Lily](/wiki/George_Lily "George
Lily")'s 1546 map divides Britain into the two kingdoms of England and
Scotland, with Ireland alongside. Some maps from this period also appear to
mark Wales, and sometimes Cornwall, as separate areas within Britain, while
the history of England created by [Polydore Vergil](/wiki/Polydore_Vergil
"Polydore Vergil")[36] for [Henry VIII](/wiki/Henry_VIII "Henry VIII") states,
"The whole country of Britain is divided into four parts, whereof the one is
inhabited by Englishmen, the other of Scots, the third Welshmen and the fourth
of Cornish people."[37][38]

Maps of the Mediaeval, Renaissance and later periods often referred to
_[Albion](/wiki/Albion "Albion")_. This archaic term was originally used by
[Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy") and [Pliny](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny
the Elder") to mean the island of Great Britain. In later centuries its
meaning changed to refer only to the area we now call Scotland (_Albany_ , or
_[Alba](/wiki/Alba "Alba")_ in [Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic_language
"Scottish Gaelic language")). _Albion_ has survived as a poetic name for
Britain but it is not in everyday use.

### 18th and 19th
centuries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 18th and 19th centuries")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Moll_-
_The_north_part_of_Great_Britain_called_Scotland.png/220px-Moll_-
_The_north_part_of_Great_Britain_called_Scotland.png)](/wiki/File:Moll_-
_The_north_part_of_Great_Britain_called_Scotland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Moll_-_The_north_part_of_Great_Britain_called_Scotland.png
"Enlarge")

A 1726 map showing "The north part of Great Britain called Scotland"

Following the [Acts of Union 1707](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707 "Acts of Union
1707"), a fashion arose, particularly in Scotland, for referring to Scotland
and England as _[North Britain](/wiki/North_Britain "North Britain")_ and
_[South Britain](/wiki/South_Britain "South Britain")_ respectively. These
terms gained in popularity during the 19th century. The most lasting example
of this usage was in the name of the [North British
Railway](/wiki/North_British_Railway "North British Railway"), which became
part of the [London and North Eastern
Railway](/wiki/London_and_North_Eastern_Railway "London and North Eastern
Railway") in 1923, and in the name of the North British Hotel, built by the
railway in [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh") in 1902, which retained
the name until it reopened in 1991 as the Balmoral Hotel.

### Evolution of kingdoms and
states[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Evolution of kingdoms and states")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Nations_of_the_UK.png/400px-
Nations_of_the_UK.png)](/wiki/File:Nations_of_the_UK.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nations_of_the_UK.png "Enlarge")

A timeline of [states](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") in the British
Isles. (_Ireland_ continues to exist, but the description "Republic of
Ireland" is used as a disambiguator in this case).

The diagram on the right gives an indication of the further evolution of
kingdoms and states. In 1603 the [Scottish King](/wiki/Scottish_King "Scottish
King") [James VI](/wiki/James_I_of_England "James I of England") inherited the
[English throne](/wiki/English_throne "English throne") as "James I of
England". He styled himself as _James I of Great Britain_ , although both
states retained their sovereignty and independent parliaments, the [Parliament
of Scotland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland "Parliament of Scotland") and the
[Parliament of England](/wiki/Parliament_of_England "Parliament of England").
(The term "Great Britain" itself reportedly dates from as early as 1474, and
was in common usage from the mid-16th century onwards.[39])

The 1707 [Act of Union](/wiki/Act_of_Union_1707 "Act of Union 1707") united
England and Scotland in the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") under the
[Parliament of Great Britain](/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain "Parliament of
Great Britain"), then in 1800 Ireland was brought under British government
control by the [Act of Union](/wiki/Act_of_Union_1800 "Act of Union 1800")
creating the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland"). Irish unrest culminated in the [Irish War of
Independence](/wiki/Anglo-Irish_War "Anglo-Irish War") and the 1922 separation
of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"), which
later became a republic with the name Ireland. The majority Protestant
[northeast](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") continued to be part of
what became the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom").

[British overseas territories](/wiki/British_overseas_territories "British
overseas territories") such as [Bermuda](/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda"),
[Gibraltar](/wiki/Gibraltar "Gibraltar") and the [Falkland
Islands](/wiki/Falkland_Islands "Falkland Islands") have various relationships
with the UK. The [Commonwealth of Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations
"Commonwealth of Nations"), initially formalised in 1931 (the British
Commonwealth until 1949), is an association of independent states roughly
corresponding to the former [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British
Empire"). (This has no connection with the [Commonwealth of
England](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_England "Commonwealth of England"), a short-
lived [republic](/wiki/Republic "Republic") replacing the previous kingdoms
during the [English Interregnum](/wiki/English_Interregnum "English
Interregnum") (1649–1660).)

##
Adjectives[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Adjectives")]

The [adjectives](/wiki/Adjectives "Adjectives") used to describe the contents
and attributes of the various constituent parts of the British Isles also
cause confusion.

In the absence of a single adjective to refer to the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), _British_ is generally used
to refer to the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") as a
whole. However, in a specifically physical geographical sense, _British_ is
used to refer to the island of [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great
Britain").[40] The adjectival phrase _Great British_ is very rarely used to
refer to [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), other than to
contrive a [pun](/wiki/Pun "Pun") on the word _great_ , as in "Great British
Food".

_Irish_ , refers to people or a characteristic "of Ireland".[41] As such, its
meaning is contextual on the meaning of "Ireland" being used: it can relate
both to the [Irish state](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"),
and to the [island of Ireland](/wiki/Ireland_\(island\) "Ireland \(island\)").
[Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), as a
constituent part of the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United
Kingdom"), can thus be both _British_ or _Irish_ , reflected in the ability
for residents of Northern Ireland to take either British or Irish
citizenship.[42] In order to be more specific, _Northern Irish_ is therefore
in common usage. Members of the [Nationalist](/wiki/Irish_Nationalism "Irish
Nationalism") communities would not describe themselves as _British_ and would
only use the terms _Irish_ , or specifically _Northern Irish_ where needed.

The term _Ulster_ can also be used as an adjective (e.g. "[Royal Ulster
Constabulary](/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Constabulary "Royal Ulster Constabulary")"),
but this is more likely to be used by [Unionists](/wiki/Unionists_\(Ireland\)
"Unionists \(Ireland\)") and has political connotations in the same fashion as
its use as a proper noun (because only six of the traditional nine counties of
[Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"), namely [Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County
Antrim"), [Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh "County Armagh"),
[Down](/wiki/County_Down "County Down"), [Fermanagh](/wiki/County_Fermanagh
"County Fermanagh"), [Londonderry](/wiki/County_Londonderry "County
Londonderry") and [Tyrone](/wiki/County_Tyrone "County Tyrone"), are included
in Northern Ireland with the remaining three counties
[Cavan](/wiki/County_Cavan "County Cavan"), [Donegal](/wiki/County_Donegal
"County Donegal") and [Monaghan](/wiki/County_Monaghan "County Monaghan")
forming part of the Republic). The term _Ulsterman_ (or _Ulsterwoman_) is
common and holds no such political connotation. Likewise,
[Nationalists](/wiki/Irish_Nationalism "Irish Nationalism") might describe,
say, a lake in Northern Ireland as _Irish_.

Note that the geographical term [Irish Sea](/wiki/Irish_Sea "Irish Sea") thus
far appears to have escaped political connotations, even though territorial
control of the waters of the Irish Sea is divided between both the Republic of
Ireland and the UK, and also includes a British [Crown
dependency](/wiki/Crown_dependency "Crown dependency"), the [Isle of
Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man")—as yet there appears to be no
controversy with the term’s usage to mirror that of "British Isles". The
"Northern" in "Northern Ireland" is not completely accurate. The most
northerly point on the island, [Malin Head](/wiki/Malin_Head "Malin Head"), is
in the Republic of Ireland—in [County Donegal](/wiki/County_Donegal "County
Donegal")'s [Inishowen](/wiki/Inishowen "Inishowen") Peninsula.

## Problems with use of
terms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Problems with use of terms")]

### British
Isles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: British Isles")]

Main article: [British Isles naming
dispute](/wiki/British_Isles_naming_dispute "British Isles naming dispute")

The dictionary definition of [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British
Isles") is that it is a geographical term that refers to the whole of
[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland") and [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain
"Great Britain") as well as the surrounding islands. It is sometimes
incorrectly used as if identical to the UK;[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] or to
refer to [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain") and the
surrounding islands, excluding the island of [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland
"Ireland") entirely.[43][44][45] The [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") and _[The
Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_ have style guides that mandate the
dictionary definition but occasional misuse can be found on their web
sites.[46][47]

The term _[British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles")_ can also be
considered irritating or offensive by some[48] on the grounds that the modern
association of the term _British_ with the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") makes its application to
Ireland inappropriate.

The term _[British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles")_ can also be
considered to imply a proprietary title on the entire archipelago.[49]

The policy of the government of [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland") is that no
branch of government should use the term,[50] and although it is on occasion
used in a geographical sense in Irish parliamentary debates, this is often
done in a way that excludes the Republic of Ireland. In October 2006, _The
Times_ quoted a spokesman for the Irish Embassy in London as saying that they
would discourage its use.[51]

During a stop-over visit to the Republic of Ireland in 1989, the leader of the
[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), [Mikhail
Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev"), indicated that he
assumed Ireland's [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state") was
[Queen Elizabeth II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II"), given
that she was the British Queen and his officials said that Ireland was a part
of the British Isles.[52]

In [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), some
[nationalists](/wiki/Irish_nationalism "Irish nationalism") reject the term
and instead use _these islands_ , _these isles_ or "Britain and Ireland" as an
alternative.[53]

There have been several suggestions for replacements for the term _British
Isles_. Although there is no single accepted replacement, the terms _Great
Britain and Ireland_ , _The British Isles and Ireland_ and _Britain and
Ireland_ are all used.

###
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: England")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/WWII_Divide_and_Conquer_12.jpg/240px-
WWII_Divide_and_Conquer_12.jpg)](/wiki/File:WWII_Divide_and_Conquer_12.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:WWII_Divide_and_Conquer_12.jpg "Enlarge")

A still from the 1943 US propaganda film series _[Why We
Fight](/wiki/Why_We_Fight "Why We Fight")_ , which suggests that the name
"England" applies to the whole of Great Britain

The word "England" is often used synecdochically to refer to Great Britain—or
the United Kingdom as a whole[54][55]—which often causes offence, particularly
to those from the non-English parts of Britain. In a similar way, references
to England as an island,[56] to an "English passport",[57] or to Scottish or
Welsh places as being in England[57][58] are examples of this usage of the
term "England".

Because of the offence likely to be taken by Scots, Welsh and Irish at this
usage, most politicians and official figures have avoided this usage since the
early 20th century. However, there are frequent examples of this usage from
earlier times.[59][60][61] For a long time it was common for fans of the
[England football team](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team") to wave the British [Union Flag](/wiki/Union_Flag "Union
Flag")—with the use of the specifically English [St George's
Cross](/wiki/St_George%27s_Cross "St George's Cross") flag only gaining
popularity at the [Euro 96](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_96 "UEFA Euro 96") tournament.[57]

The colloquial usage of "England" as a synonym for "Britain" is still
widespread outside the UK. In [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), the term
"England" is often used to mean Great Britain or even the entire United
Kingdom. In many other languages, such as Chinese, Japanese or Korean, the
word for "English" is synonymous with "British"—see the article on
[Alternative words for
British](/wiki/Alternative_words_for_British#Other_languages "Alternative
words for British") for more detail.

###
Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Europe")]

The term "[Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe")" may be used in one of several
different contexts by British and Irish people: either to refer to the whole
of the European continent, to refer to only to [Mainland
Europe](/wiki/Mainland_Europe "Mainland Europe"), sometimes called
"continental Europe" or simply "the Continent" by some people in the
archipelago. _Europe_ may also be used in reference to the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (or, historically, to the
[European Economic Community](/wiki/European_Economic_Community "European
Economic Community")). A comedic treatment of the different uses of this word
appears in an episode of the BBC sitcom _[To the Manor
Born](/wiki/To_the_Manor_Born "To the Manor Born")_. When tradesmen are taking
measurements in metric, and Audrey fforbes-Hamilton objects on the grounds
that the house was built "in feet and inches", a tradesman says "We're in
Europe now", referring to the European Economic Community. Audrey fforbes-
Hamilton retorts "Well you may be, but I'm staying here!" \- implying that to
her, the word "Europe" referred only to mainland Europe, excluding Britain and
Ireland.

### Great
Britain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Great Britain")]

The word "Great" means "larger", in comparison with [Brittany](/wiki/Brittany
"Brittany") in modern-day [France](/wiki/France "France"). One historical term
for the [peninsula](/wiki/Peninsula "Peninsula") in France that largely
corresponds to the modern French province is _Lesser_ or _Little Britain_.
That region was settled by many British immigrants during the period of
[Anglo-Saxon](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons "Anglo-Saxons") migration into Britain, and
named "Little Britain" by them. The [French](/wiki/French_language "French
language") term "Bretagne" now refers to the French "Little Britain", not to
the British "Great Britain", which in French is called _Grande-Bretagne_. In
classical times, the [Graeco-Roman](/wiki/Greco-Roman_world "Greco-Roman
world") geographer [Ptolemy](/wiki/Geography_\(Ptolemy\) "Geography
\(Ptolemy\)") in his _[Almagest](/wiki/Almagest "Almagest")_ also called the
larger island _megale Brettania_ (great Britain). At that time, it was in
contrast to the smaller island of [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), which he
called _mikra Brettania_ (little Britain).[62] In his later work
_[Geography](/wiki/Geography_\(Ptolemy\) "Geography \(Ptolemy\)")_ , Ptolemy
refers to Great Britain as _Albion_ and to Ireland as
_[Iwernia](/wiki/Hibernia "Hibernia")_. These "new" names were likely to have
been the native names for the islands at the time. The earlier names, [in
contrast](/wiki/Exonym_and_endonym "Exonym and endonym"), were likely to have
been coined before direct contact with local peoples was made.[63]

###
Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Ireland")]

The word _Ireland_ has two meanings.

  1. It is the official name of [the state](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") that occupies five sixths of the island, formally named the Republic of Ireland.
  2. It is a geographical term for [the whole island](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), which may be referred to as "the island of Ireland" to avoid ambiguity.

###
Ulster[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Ulster")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/IrelandUlster.svg/220px-
IrelandUlster.svg.png)](/wiki/File:IrelandUlster.svg)

[](/wiki/File:IrelandUlster.svg "Enlarge")

The traditional province of Ulster on the island of Ireland, showing the
modern-day border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland

The terminology and usage of the name _Ulster_ in Irish and British culture
varies. Many within the [unionist](/wiki/Unionist_\(Ireland\) "Unionist
\(Ireland\)") community[64] and much of the UK press refer to [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") as _Ulster_ – whereas the
[nationalist](/wiki/Irish_nationalism "Irish nationalism") community refer to
the traditional [Irish province](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of
Ireland") of [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"), which is a nine-county entity
that incorporates the three counties of [Donegal](/wiki/County_Donegal "County
Donegal"), [Cavan](/wiki/County_Cavan "County Cavan") and
[Monaghan](/wiki/County_Monaghan "County Monaghan") (which are in the
Republic) along with the counties of [Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh "County
Armagh"), [Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County Antrim"),
[Down](/wiki/County_Down "County Down"), [Fermanagh](/wiki/County_Fermanagh
"County Fermanagh"), [Londonderry](/wiki/County_Londonderry "County
Londonderry") and [Tyrone](/wiki/Tyrone "Tyrone") in Northern Ireland.

Thus, the word _Ulster_ has two usages:

  1. It is the name of [one](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") of the four [Provinces of Ireland](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of Ireland"), consisting of the nine northern counties of the island, that was partitioned between the United Kingdom (six counties) and the Republic of Ireland (three counties).
  2. It is an alternative name for [Northern Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland"), used by many in the [Unionist](/wiki/Irish_Unionism "Irish Unionism") community. It consists of the six north-eastern counties of the island that remain part of the United Kingdom.

## Further
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Further information")]

### Isle of Man and Channel
Islands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Isle of Man and Channel Islands")]

The Isle of Man and the two [bailiwicks](/wiki/Bailiwick "Bailiwick") of the
Channel Islands are [Crown dependencies](/wiki/Crown_dependencies "Crown
dependencies"); that is, non-sovereign [nations](/wiki/Nation "Nation"), self-
governing but whose sovereignty is held by the British [Crown](/wiki/The_Crown
"The Crown"). They control their own internal affairs, but not their defence
or foreign relations. They are not part of the United Kingdom or part of the
[European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").

  * The [Isle of Man](/wiki/Isle_of_Man "Isle of Man") is part of the [British Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles"), situated in the [Irish Sea](/wiki/Irish_Sea "Irish Sea") between Great Britain and Ireland.
  * The [Channel Islands](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") consist politically of two self-governing [bailiwicks](/wiki/Bailiwick "Bailiwick"): the [Bailiwick of Guernsey](/wiki/Bailiwick_of_Guernsey "Bailiwick of Guernsey") and the [Bailiwick of Jersey](/wiki/Jersey "Jersey"). They are the remnants of the [Duchy of Normandy](/wiki/Duchy_of_Normandy "Duchy of Normandy"), which was once in [personal union](/wiki/Personal_union "Personal union") with the Kingdom of England. They are sometimes, despite their location next to mainland [France](/wiki/France "France"), considered part of the British Isles. This usage is political rather than geographic.
  * The Isle of Man and the Channel Islands are [British Islands](/wiki/British_Islands "British Islands") in United Kingdom law.

### Celtic
names[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Celtic names")]

There are five living [Celtic languages](/wiki/Celtic_languages "Celtic
languages") in the region. Each has names for the islands and countries of the
British Isles. They are divided into two branches:

  * [Brythonic](/wiki/Brythonic_languages "Brythonic languages") – which includes [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") and [Cornish](/wiki/Cornish_language "Cornish language")
  * [Goidelic](/wiki/Goidelic_languages "Goidelic languages") – which includes [Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"), [Scottish Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic_language "Scottish Gaelic language") and [Manx](/wiki/Manx_language "Manx language")

Some of the above are:

**English** | Cornwall | Wales | Ireland | Northern  
Ireland | Republic of  
Ireland | Scotland | Mann | England  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
**Cornish**  
(Kernewek) | Kernow | Kembra | Iwerdhon | Iwerdhon Gledh | Repoblek  
Iwerdhon | Alban | Manow | Pow an Sawson  
**Welsh**  
(Cymraeg) | Cernyw | Cymru | Iwerddon | Gogledd Iwerddon | Gweriniaeth  
Iwerddon | Yr Alban | Manaw | Lloegr  
**Irish**  
(Gaeilge) | an Chorn | an Bhreatain Bheag | Éire | Tuaisceart Éireann | Poblacht na  
hÉireann | Albain | Manainn | Sasana  
**Scottish Gaelic**  
(Gàidhlig) | a' Chòrn | a' Chuimrigh | Èirinn | Èirinn a Tuath | Poblachd na  
h-Èireann | Alba | Manainn | Sasann  
**Manx**  
(Gaelg) | y Chorn | Bretyn | Nerin | Nerin Hwoaie | Pobblaght  
Nerin | Nalbin | Mannin | Sostyn  
  
The English word _Welsh_ is from a common [Germanic](/wiki/Germanic_languages
"Germanic languages") root meaning "Romanised foreigner"
([cognate](/wiki/Cognate "Cognate") with [Wallonia](/wiki/Wallonia "Wallonia")
and [Wallachia](/wiki/Wallachia "Wallachia"), and also cognate with the word
used in Mediaeval German to refer to the French and [Italians](/wiki/Italy
"Italy")).[65]

The English names _[Albion](/wiki/Albion "Albion")_ and
_[Albany](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland")_ are related to _Alba_ and used
poetically for either England or Scotland, or the whole island of Great
Britain.

English _[Erin](/wiki/Erin "Erin")_ is a poetic name for Ireland derived from
_Éire_ (or rather, from its dative form _Éirinn_).

### Terms for the British Isles in the Irish
language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Terms for the British Isles in the Irish language")]

In Irish, the term _Oileáin Bhriotanacha_ is a translation of the English term
_British Isles_. Another translation is _Oileáin Bhreataineacha_ , which was
used in the 1937 translation from English to Irish of a 1931 geography
book.[66]

Earlier dictionaries[67] give _Oileáin Iarthair Eorpa_ as the translation,
literally meaning _West European Isles_. Today the most common term _Éire agus
an Bhreatain Mhór_ is used, meaning literally as _Ireland and Great Britain_ ,
as provided by terminological dictionaries.[68]

##
Slang[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Terminology_of_the_British_Isles&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Slang")]

_[Blighty](/wiki/Blighty "Blighty")_ is a slang word for Britain derived from
the [Hindustani](/wiki/Hindustani_language "Hindustani language") word
_bilāyatī_ ("foreign"). Depending on the user, it is meant either
affectionately or archly. It was often used by British soldiers abroad in the
[First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War") to refer to home.
